“That is a very good reason preventing attempts to deal with a judge's salary as such, but
seems to me no reason for exonerating him from the ordinary duties of a citizen, which he
shares  will  all  others. To  require  a  man to  pay  the  taxes  that  all  other men  have  to pay
cannot  be  possibly  made  an  instrument  to  attack  the  independence  as  a  judge.  I  see
nothing in the purpose of this clause of the Constitution to indicate that the judges were
to be a privileged class, free from bearing their share of the cost of the institution upon
which their well-being if not their life depends. We are of the view that the reasoning in
the above cases is logical and instructive on the issue of taxes on the salaries of judges.
When  a  tax  is  applied  across  the  board,  as  in  this  case,  without  directly  or  indirectly
targeting  the  judges,  it  cannot  be  said  to  be  an  intrusion  into  the  independence  of  the
Judiciary.  Taxes  are  one  of  the  main  revenues  generating  measures  to  enhance  public
finance.  Facilities  are  open  to  all  citizenry  including  judges  of  the  superior  courts  and
judicial officers within the meaning of Article 111M of the Constitution.”
